Scheme 1 Catalytic cycloaddition of carbon dioxide with epoxide to produce cyclic carbonates. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Synthesis of protic bis-benzimidazolium salts. Scheme 2 Scheme 3 Catalytic cycle for bifunctional bis-benzimidazoles catalysts system. Scheme 3 Fig. 1 Crystal structures for compounds 2Cl, 2I, 3Br, 4Br and 5Br. The thermal ellipsoids were drawn with 50% probability for non-hydrogen atoms, their counter-ions and co-crystallized water molecules. Some atoms were omitted for clarity and NH and water hydrogens are drawn as arbitrary radius spheres. Dashed cyan lines represent hydrogen bonds. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Effect of PO amount: Reaction conditions: 2Br (1 mol%), T (100 °C), reaction time (3 h), pressure (30 bar). (b) Effect of temperature; reaction conditions: PO (50 mmol), 2Br (1 mol%), pressure (30 bar), time (3 h). (c) Effect of time; reaction conditions: PO (50 mmol), 2Br (1 mol%), T (120 °C), pressure (30 bar). (d) Effect of pressure; reaction conditions: PO (50 mmol), 2Br (1 mol%), T (120 °C), t (1 h). (e) Effect of catalyst load; reaction conditions: PO (50 mmol), 2Br (1 mol%), T (120 °C), pressure (15 bar), t (1 h). (f) Effect of water content; reaction conditions: PO (50 mmol), 2Br (0.75 mol%), T (120 °C), pressure (15 bar), t (1 h). Fig 2 Fig. 3 Synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and various epoxides. Reaction conditions: Epoxide (50 mmol), 2Br (0.75 mol%), CO2 pressure (30 bar), temperature (120 °C), time (2 h). Conversion of epoxide to the respective cyclic carbonate was determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy analysis; values in parentheses for propylene carbonate and chloropropylene carbonate refer to the isolated yield. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Reusability of 2Br. Reaction conditions: PO (25 mmol), 2Br (0.75 mol%), CO2 pressure (30 bar), temperature (120 °C), time (2 h). Selecitivity to PC was > 99% in all cycles. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Blue: 1H NMR of 0.02 mmol of 2Br in DMSO‑d6 . Red: 1H NMR of 2Br (0.02 mmol) and SO (0.04 mmol) in t = 0, T = 25 °C. Integrating signal were done only to the catalyst. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Red: 1H NMR of 2Br (0.02 mmol), SO (0.04 mmol) and t = 0, T = 25 °C. Blue: 1H NMR of 2Br (0.02 mmol), SO (0.04 mmol) and t = 0, T = 50 °C. A series of 1,2-bis(benzimidazolium)ethane dihydrohalide salts was prepared and characterized, including five structures elucidated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. These compounds were tested as organocatalysts for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates. Effects of counteranions, N-substituents and C-5 substituents, and how they affect solubility in the catalytic system, were evaluated. The salts containing 1,2-bis(5-methyl-benzimidazolium)ethane cation presented the best activities and the one with bromide as counteranion (2Br) was selected to carry out a study of several parameters of the catalytic system. Various epoxides could be selectively converted to the respective cyclic carbonate and, reuse experiments were conducted, showing that catalyst 2Br can be reused at least six times, with no decline in conversion and selectivity. In addition, a catalytic mechanism was carefully proposed, taking into account 1H NMR spectroscopy experiments. Simple, nontoxic and low cost synthetic route to obtain the catalysts, as well as the high conversions using low catalyst loading, make this class of catalysts promising for the use of carbon dioxide in the production of cyclic carbonates. Graphical abstract bis-Benzimidazolium salts were designed to be used as bifunctional organocatalysts for the production of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides. Crystal structures, mechanistic studies and reuse experiments are the highlight of this study. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon dioxide Organocatalysis Hydrogen bond Bifunctional Cyclic carbonate Benzimidazole Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide has become the main anthropogenic gas responsible for global warming [1]. Its concentration in the atmosphere has increased rapidly since the industrial revolution from 210 to 414 ppm in 2021 [2]. The high levels of CO2 in the atmosphere, concerns about climate change and public pressure for benign and greener processes have prompted scientists around the world to study the development of methodologies to use and prevent the release of CO2. In this sense, routes to produce value-added products from CO2 and mitigate its emissions have been extensively investigated. In the last decades, the search for the replacement of fossil resources by CO2 in the chemical industry chain has gained great attention; however, an amount equivalent to only 0.03% of the world's CO2 emissions is used industrially in CO2-based processes to manufacture mainly urea, salicylic acid and carbonates [3]. The chemical conversion of CO2 is hampered by its kinetic and thermodynamic inertness, which implies, in general, the use of high temperatures and pressures, the employment of high-energy substrates, and/or the need to use a catalyst [4,5]. The production of cyclic organic carbonates (COC's) (Scheme 1 ) is one of the most viable processes that use CO2 efficiently as a feedstock [6–8]. The industrial synthesis of ethylene/propylene carbonates from CO2 and epoxides catalyzed by quaternary ammonium halides have been known since the 1950s [9]. The COC's can be widely used as polar aprotic solvents, solvents for electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries, monomers for the production of polymers, intermediates in the production of fine chemicals, etc. [10–12]. A variety of catalysts have been reported for the synthesis of COC's from CO2 and epoxides, such as, inter alia, metal complexes, MOF's, alkali metal salts, onium salts, organocatalysts and ionic liquids, which have been accounted recently in a series of excellent review articles [13–22]. Most of these examples are based on the activation of the epoxide ring, although methodologies that focus on the activation of CO2 or dual activation of CO2 and epoxide have also been described [23–26]. Metal-free organocatalysts have gained special attention due to recent major efforts to make industrial processes eco-friendlier while maintaining their efficiency [3,27–29]. Nucleophilic/basic organocatalysts, as for example carbenes, and anionic nitrogen-based heterocycles, catalyze the reactions through nucleophilic attack on CO2, forming nucleophilic intermediates that then open the epoxide ring [30–35]. On the other hand, organocatalysts with proton containing functional groups, such as -OH, -COOH or -NH-, can activate the epoxide ring by forming strong hydrogen bonds, facilitating its ring opening by the attack of a nucleophile, and thus are called hydrogen bond donors (HBDs). Hydrogen-bond donors can have varying acidity, from mild to essentially strong Brønsted acids. D’ Elia et al. investigated the correlation between the catalytic activity of hydroxyl HBDs in the cycloaddition of CO2 with epichlorohydrin and their Brønsted acidity, expressed by the pKa of the most acidic proton in the HBD molecule [36]; they concluded that a high Brønsted acidity is likely to have a positive impact on H-bonding ability and in the ring opening of the epoxide, however, it may slow down the release of the product in the cyclization step. Highly acidic Brønsted acid HBD catalysts might lead to protonation of crucial reaction intermediates; proton transfer from the HBD catalyst to the open epoxide intermediate, for example, would lead to a halohydrine and prevent the reaction from proceeding. Thus, it is necessary to develop HBD catalysts with adequate Brønsted acidity that are good hydrogen-bond donors, activating and facilitating the ring opening of the epoxide, without transferring the proton to the intermediates, which would hinder the efficient production of the desired cyclic carbonates. HBDs have emerged as an interesting class of catalysts for the activation of epoxides, either in binary or bifunctional catalytic systems [36–42]. The system is said to be bifunctional if the same compound that is activating the epoxide is also the source of the nucleophile, synergistically activating and opening the epoxide ring, as opposed to binary catalytic systems that use an epoxide activator and a nucleophile source as separate components [43]. In this sense, HBD bifunctional organocatalysts, such as protic organic salts containing E-H polar bonds (E = heteroatom or C sp2 ) and a nucleophilic counteranion are of great interest to perform single component catalysis for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides. Salts of N-heterocyclic compounds have been rather studied for this purpose [15,38,44–47]. For instance, imidazolium based protic ionic liquids were employed as catalysts and produced much better results when compared to the analogous pyridinium and triethylammonium bromides, suggesting that the positive charge density would be responsible for a decrease in catalytic activity of the latter [48]. Also, functionalized bis-N-imidazolium bromides have been reported as efficient catalysts for the cycloaddition of various epoxides and CO2 [46,49]. Based on experimental results and DFT calculations, the authors stated that the three hydrogen donors (combined effect of two imidazole Csp2 H and -OH group) are crucial for stabilizing the alkoxide and carbonate intermediates and also for activating the epoxide [49]. Also, the effects of the hydrogen donor groups -OH and -COOH, the N-substituents as well as the length of the carbon bridge were investigated [46]. More recently, it was reported that the synergism between the hydroxyl group and the counteranion of HO-functionalized 1,2,3- triazole-based ionic liquids catalysts is essential for achieving excellent activities for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates using CO2 [50]. Also, a three-component catalytic system involving pyridine-bridged benzimidazolium salts, CrCl2, and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) was reported [51], being the first example of the use of benzimidazolium salts for the cycloaddition of epoxides with CO2. In turn, we decided to explore benzimidazolium salts in a different way, as bifunctional hydrogen-bond donor catalysts containing two catalytic sites on a single unit of bisbenzimidazolium. Notwithstanding there are several studies with HBDs as organocatalysts for the coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides, the development of efficient metal-free bifunctional catalysts prepared through a straightforward, low-cost route is still a relevant research target. Recently, our group reported the first examples of metal complexes bearing benzimidazole-derived ligands as catalysts for the CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides [52,53]. In this work, we report a series of eight 1,2-bis(benzimidazolium)ethane dihydrohalides (Scheme 2 ) as bifunctional organocatalysts and examined their activity for the cycloaddition of CO2 and various epoxides. The catalysts were synthesized and characterized by 1H and 13C NMR, IR spectroscopy and high resolution mass spectrometry. Additionally, compounds 2Br, 3Br, 4Br and 6Cl have their structures determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Furthermore, 1H NMR studies were performed to investigate the mechanism of this catalytic system. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and instrumentation All reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and were used as received (ACS reagent grade). Carbon dioxide gas (99.99%) was purchased from Air Liquide and used without further purification. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 400 FT-IR instrument using KBr pellets over the range of 4000–400 cm−1. NMR spectra (1H and 13C) were acquired at 20 °C on a Bruker AVANCE III 500 MHz spectrometer operating at 11.75 T; chemical shifts are given in δ (ppm) and relate to the TMS signal at δ 0.00 as an internal reference. ESI (+) MS analyses were performed on a microQTOF-Q III (Bruker Daltoniks, GmbH) in full scan mode by direct infusion at a flow rate of 3.8 L min−1. The samples were dissolved in methanol to a concentration of 10 µg mL−1. The electrospray source was operated in positive mode with capillary voltage set at 4000 V and using high purity nitrogen as desolvation, nebulizer and collision gas. For desolvation, the temperature was kept at 200 °C, and the nebulizer pressure was kept at 0.3 bar. 2.2 Synthesis All the syntheses were adapted from classical methodologies already reported [54–57]. The general procedure for the synthesis of all compounds is shown in Scheme 2 and described below: 2.2.1 Compounds 1 and 2 A solution of succinic acid (5 mmol, 0.590 g) in 5 mL of HCl 4 mol/L was slowly added to a solution of o-phenylenediamine (11 mmol, 1.19 g), or 4-methyl-o-phenylenediamine (11 mmol, 1.34 g ), in 15 mL of aqueous HCl 4 mol/L, to obtain 1 and 2, respectively. The mixture was stirred for 24 h under reflux and then cooled in an ice bath, forming a crystalline precipitate. The solid was filtered off, washed three times with cold water (3 × 5 mL), and dried under reduced pressure to produce 2.57 g of 1.2HCl (70% yield) or 2.99 g of 2.2HCl (75% yield). Neutral bis-benzimidazoles 1 and 2 were obtained by neutralization of 1.2HCl and 2.2HCl, using two equivalents of aqueous NaOH. A suspension of the compounds was stirred for 2 h at 25 °C, changing the color from green to pink. The resulting solid was washed with distilled water (3 × 5 mL) and dried under vacuum, quantitatively providing the neutral compounds. 2.2.2 Compounds 1Br, 2Cl, 2Br and 2I Compounds 1 or 2 (5 mmol) were suspended in 15 mL of distilled water, then the desired HX (HCl, HBr or HI, aqueous solution, 2 equivalents, 10 mmol) was added and the mixture was stirred for 2 h at 25 °C. The resulting solid was filtered and dried under reduced pressure (6 h at 60 °C) to generate the protic salts 1,2-bis(1-H-benzimidazolium)ethane dihydrobromide (1Br), 1,2-bis(5-methyl-benzimidazolium)ethane dihydrobromide (2Br), 1,2-bis(5-methyl-benzimidazolium)ethane dihydrochloride (2Cl) and 1,2-bis(5-methyl-benzimidazolium)ethane dihydroiodide (2I). 2.2.3 Compounds 3Br, 4Br and 5Br 2-Bis(benzimidazol-2-yl)ethane 1 (5 mmol) was suspended in 20 mL of dry acetonitrile and then sodium hydride (11 mmol, in acetonitrile) was added dropwise at 25 °C under N2 atmosphere. The reaction mixture was stirred for 3 h until complete color change from pink to white, indicating the double deprotonation of 1. Next, 11 mmol of bromoalkane (RBr; 3, R = Me; 4, R = Et; 5, R = Bu) was carefully added and the reaction was kept stirring for 48 h at 25 °C. The crude reaction mixture was concentrated and the resulting white solid was washed with distilled water (3 × 5 mL) and dried under reduced pressure. The respective salts were obtained in the same way as the salts of 2, producing: 1,2-bis(1-methyl-benzimidazolium)ethane dihydrobromide (3Br), 1,2-bis(1-ethyl-benzimidazolium)ethane dihydrobromide (4Br), 1,2-bis(1-buthyl-benzimidazolium)ethane dihydrobromide (5Br). 2.2.4 Compounds 6 and 6Br Glacial acetic acid (4 mL) and concentrated sulfuric acid (10 mL) were added to 2-bis(benzimidazol-2-yl)ethane 1 (5 mmol, 1.31 g) in a round bottom flask cooled in an ice bath and the mixture was stirred for 1 h. Next, 5 mL of H2SO4 conc. and HNO3 conc. (6:4 mixture) was dropwise added to the solution. After 3 h, the mixture was neutralized using aqueous NaOH and the resulting solid was filtered off and washed with water, furnishing 6. The respective 6Br salt was obtained in the same way as the 2Br. 2.2.5 Characterization data All synthesized compounds were characterized by 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopy, vibrational infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and high resolution mass spectrometry. 1Br : Yield: 78%, light green solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO‑d6 , ppm): 7.81 (4H, dd, J = 6.14 and 3.16 Hz), 7.54 (4H, dd, J = 6.17 and 3.15 Hz), 3.81 (4H, s). 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO‑d6 , ppm): 151.48, 131.12, 125.61, 113.90, 23.79. ESI-HRMS: [M-2Br-H]+: m/z calculated 353.0993, found 353.1034. 2.3 X-ray diffraction analysis Plate-shaped single crystals of 2Cl, 3Br, 4Br and 5Br were obtained through slow evaporation from ethanol solutions and then mounted on a κ-goniostat of a Bruker-AXS Kappa Duo diffractometer equipped with an APEX II CCD detector and then exposed to X-ray beam (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Crystallographic programs were used as follows: APEX2 (data collection strategy setup with φ and ω scans and κ offsets) [58], SAINT (indexing, integration and scaling of raw data) [58], SHELXS (structure solving using Direct Methods) [59], SHELXL (structure refinement by full-matrix least squares method on F2) [60] and MERCURY (structure analysis and graphical representations) [61]. Single light colorless prism-shaped crystals of 2I were obtained through slow evaporation from ethanol solution. A suitable crystal was selected and diffraction data were collected using a SuperNova, Dual, Cu at home/near, AtlasS2 diffractometer, operating at T = 290.24(18) K, using ω- scans of 1.0 per frame and MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data reduction, cell parameters and a gaussian absorption correction were performed using the CrysAlisPro (Rigaku, V1.171.39.46e, 2018) software. Using Olex2 [62], the structure was solved with the ShelXT [60] structure solution program by Intrinsic Phasing method and the model was refined with ShelXL [60] using least squares minimization. All non-hydrogen atoms of asymmetric units were directly known from the electronic density Fourier synthesis. Free anisotropic and fixed isotropic (Uiso(H) = 1.2Uiso(C) or 1.5Uiso(CCH3 or O)) atomic displacement parameters were applied to non-hydrogen and hydrogen atoms, respectively. All CH hydrogens were placed at constrained sites following a riding model for bond lengths and angles. NH and water hydrogens were also not refined freely, however they were first seen in the difference Fourier map and then checked for correct intramolecular and intermolecular bonding geometry before final constraints. CCDC deposit codes 2001195, 2001193, 2001194 and 2001192 correspond to 2Cl, 3Br, 4Br and 5Br, respectively, and 2015098 to 2I. 2.4 Catalytic system for the reaction of CO2 with epoxides Catalytic reactions for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides were conducted in a Parr reactor system (model 4560 with controller model 4848) equipped with a 300 mL stainless steel vessel and magnetic stirrer. In a typical run, the vessel was charged with the organocatalyst and the epoxide. Carbon dioxide was pressurized into the mixture and the reaction was carried out under predetermined conditions. After the reaction is complete, the vessel was cooled in an ice/salt cooling bath at temperatures below 0 °C and the pressure was slowly released. A sample of the crude reaction mixture was dissolved in deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) and analyzed by 1H NMR. The conversion was calculated based on the 1H NMR spectrum of the crude reaction mixture thus obtained by the integral ratio between epoxide and cyclic carbonate, similarly to the methods reported in several articles [63–70]. 1H NMR spectra for the various epoxides employed in the reaction are given in the ESI and, NMR profile of all cyclic carbonates was compared to the spectra already reported in the literature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of bis(benzimidazolium) salts As mentioned in previous section, the synthesis procedures were adapted from previously reported methodologies [54–57] and are detailed in Scheme 2. Pure compounds were obtained as solids by direct precipitation from the reaction medium, in good yields, without the need for additional purification steps. Characterization by NMR and IR spectroscopy and ESI-HRMS confirmed the expected products. 3.2 Crystal structures of compounds 2Cl, 2I, 3Br, 4Br and 5Br Crystal structures for compounds 2Cl, 2I, 3Br, 4Br and 5Br are depicted in Fig. 1 . Table S4 exhibits the crystallographic data for the crystalline structures obtained in this work. Compound 2Cl crystallized in the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/c as a dihydrochloride salt dihydrate as seen in Fig. S40. It is also possible to observe that the methyl group, attached to the benzimidazole ring, presents a positional disorder in the proportion 50:50. The C1-N1 and C1-N2 bonds have distances at 1.28(2) Å and 1.33(16) Å, respectively, suggesting a conjugation on the imidazole ring. In the crystal structure, π-π interactions are formed where the molecules are interspersed, similar to what occurs in compounds 3Br and 4Br, building the crystalline packaging, but the bis-benzimidazole molecules are stacked in the form of zig-zag ( ab plane) with centroid-centroid distance at 3.629 Å and shift distance at 1.178 Å (Plane 1: C7 C6 C5 C4 C3 C2) as shown in Figs. S45 and S46, where water molecules are responsible for most of the interactions present as well as the extension of the structure along the c-axis. The compound 2I belongs to the P 1 ¯ space group with Z = 2 (Z’ = 0.5), which represents 2 molecules in the unit cell and similar to what happened with another compounds, the asymmetric unit (ASU) also contains one H2O molecule, one I − ion and half-protonated bis-benzimidazole molecule, asserting this compound crystallizes as a di-hydrate (Fig. S43). Similar to compound 2Cl, the CN bond in this compound suggests a conjugation on the imidazole ring (1.329(4) Å). The main weak intermolecular hydrogen bonds stabilize the crystal network in 2I (Fig. S44). No stacking interaction is observed, on the other hand, the bis-benzimidazoles molecules show hydrogen bonding through NH groups that extend along the b-axis forming a two-dimensional sheet, where N–H…I and OH…H hydrogen bonding were observed, of which these ones interact with each other through van der Waals interactions. Compounds 3Br and 4Br have crystallized in centrosymmetric triclinic space group P 1 ¯ as di-hydrobromide salt di-hydrate with Z = 2, i. e., two bromide counter-ions and two crystallization water to each di-protonated bis-benzimidazole portion. One molecule and another half of the compound 3Br is present in its ASU together with three Br− and three H2O molecules, while for the compound 4Br, the ASU is formed by half benzimidazole molecule, one Br− and one H2O molecule. Crystal structure in both compounds is generated by inversion symmetry (Fig. S46). Despite some experimental difficulties in determining crystalline structures, the geometric parameters (bond and angles) for compounds are in agreement with those of the similar compounds described in the literature [71]. Selected bond distances and bond angles for all compounds in this work are listed in Table S1. Selected torsion angles are given in Table S2. The C–N bond lengths in the imidazole ring for compound 3Br are in the range of 1.26(6) to 1.42(6) Å while for the compound 4Br are of 1.319(11) to 1.331(9) Å, and indicates a modification of the double bond character. In the crystalline structure of these compounds, there is the formation of a chain of unconventional hydrogen bonds (H…Br…H), which is responsible for stabilizing the compounds along the crystallographic a -axis, as can be seen in Fig. S47 and listed in Table S3. The bis-benzimidazoles present in the formed chains are interspersed, making the crystalline packaging stabilized by weak π-π type interactions with centroid-centroid distance at 3.752 Å, 3.515 Å and shift distance at 1.568 Å, 1.164 Å (Plane 1: C12 C13 C14 C15 C16 C11) and centroid-centroid distance: at 3.579 Å, 3.776 Å and shift distance 1.275 Å, 1.669 Å (Plane 2: C7 C6 C5 C4 C3 C2) for compound 3Br and for compound 4Br, there are values of 3.620 Å for the centroid-centroid distance and 1.025 Å for the shift distance (Plan 1: C7 C6 C5 C4 C3 C2) as shown in Fig. S32. Compound 5Br has been solved in the non-centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P2 1 as a dihydrobromide salt (one di-protonated molecule and two Br- in the ASU, Fig. S48). The benzimidazole rings are planar, however, the CN bond lengths on the imidazole ring are different with values of 1.40(6) and 1.10(5) for C10-N3 and C10-N4 bond, respectively, while for C1-N2 and C1-N1 bonds are 1.52 (6) and of 1.34(5). With the exception of the C10-N4 bond, all others have a greater distance from the typical C = N bond, and this suggests a different behavior from the CN bond in the substituted imidazole rings. Although the compound shows interactions of type H…Br…H, the stabilization of the structure occurs basically through interactions of van der Waals (vdW), as seen Fig. S49. Unlike what occurs in compounds 3Br and 4Br, no π-π interactions were found, since the rings are much more displaced in relation to each other. When matching compounds 3Br, 4Br and 5Br, it is observed that the N substitution of -methyl, -ethyl and ‑butyl groups cause a change in the twisting of the alkyl chain between the bis-benzimidazole rings and so, this change in torsion leads to a reduction in π-π interactions. From the crystallographic results, it is possible to suggest that the N-substitution of benzimidazole nitrogen could be used to control the conformation, as well as the type of interactions in the crystalline structure. 3.3 Catalytic studies Initially, 1,2-bis(benzimidazolium)ethane dihydrobromide salts (1Br – 6Br) were tested as catalysts for the cycloaddition reaction between propylene oxide (PO) and CO2, without addition of any cocatalyst, under the following conditions: 30 bar of pressure, at 100 °C, in 3 h, using 25 mmol of PO and 1 mol% of catalyst (Table 1 ). Compounds 1Br, 3Br and 4Br were insoluble in the reaction medium and, for this reason, no conversion of PO to propylene carbonate (PC) was observed (entries 2, 6 and 8, Table 1). To ensure all catalysts were solubilized, the reactions were also conducted in the presence of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as a solvent, which provided some catalytic activity for the insoluble compounds (entries 3, 7 and 9, Table 1). Compound 5Br with N‑butyl substituent (R2 = n-Bu) was partially soluble in the epoxide and provided 15% of conversion (entry 10, Table 1), in contrast with the non-active compounds with shorter N-alkyl substituents 3Br (N-methyl, R2 = Me) and 4Br (N-ethyl, R2 = Et) which were insoluble. It was previously observed for bridge-functionalized bis-imidazolium bromides that longer N-alkyl substituents increase the solubility of the compounds in the reaction medium, providing better catalytic activity [46,49]. In an attempt to simultaneously improve the solubility of the compounds and evaluate the presence of electron-withdrawing and electron-donating groups, compounds 2Br (C5-methyl substituted, R1 = CH3) and 6Br (C5-nitro substituted, R1 = NO2) were tested in the catalytic system. Compound 6Br was unfortunately insoluble and it was not able to convert PO to PC (entry 12, Table 1). On the other hand, compound 2Br showed a synergism between solubility and adequate Brønsted acidity, which was essential to achieve 50% of conversion, selectively producing propylene carbonate without the use of DMSO as a solvent (entry 4, Table 1). Subsequently, other two C5-methyl substituted bis-benzimidazolium salts containing chloride (2Cl) and iodide (2I) as counteranions were produced in order to evaluate the influence of anions with different nucleophilicities on the catalytic system. The order of conversion followed the nucleophilicity in polar protic media; as chloride has stronger interactions with the protons of imidazole, this decreases its nucleophilic capacity. In contrast, bromide and iodide anions have weaker interactions and are more available to attack the epoxide, opening the ring. Also, iodide is the best leaving group among the three anions, decreasing the activation energy in the ring closure step that give rise to the cyclic carbonate [72]. Thus, the conversions obtained for 2Cl, 2Br and 2I were 12%, 50% and 83%, respectively, in agreement with the order reported for other organocatalysts [73–75]. In the following steps, a series of reaction parameters were evaluated using 2Br as catalyst, without the use of any additive or solvent. Although 2I produced the highest conversion, optimization was performed with the less expensive 2Br catalyst in order to develop a low-cost catalytic system. First, the influence of the amount of epoxide in the system was evaluated (Fig. 2 a). It was observed that by increasing PO amount to 50 mmol, the conversion improved from 50% to 78%. When 100 and 200 mmol of PO were used, the conversions reached 85% and 88%, respectively. Temperature had a great influence on the catalytic cycloaddition of PO with CO2 (Fig. 2b). Below 80 °C, PO conversions were very low: 1% at 60 °C and 11% at 70 °C. Nearly quantitative conversions were achieved at 110 °C and 130 °C. In contrast to what was reported in other systems [43,76–78], there was no loss of selectivity at such high temperatures. When evaluating the reaction time, a faster reaction rate was observed at the beginning, as expected, converting 28% of PO in 15 min (Fig. 2c). The maximum TOF of 132 h−1 was reached in 30 min of reaction, and in 3 h the conversion was quantitative. The effect of CO2 pressure was evaluated in one-hour reactions, showing a large increase in conversions from 5 bar to 10 bar (Fig. 2d). It can be suggested that, under low pressure (5 bar), the insertion of CO2 should be a rate-determining step of the reaction, explaining the lower conversion (32%). By increasing the pressure, more CO2 was soluble in the reaction medium, providing better conversions [79,80]. The high activity remained almost constant over the pressure range between 10 and 30 bar, suggesting that CO2 insertion is no longer the rate-determining step [48]. At 40 bar, the conversion decreased; excessive CO2 pressure causes the dilution of epoxide and catalyst, which decreases the activity of the system [80,81]. Fig. 2e shows the influence of the catalyst load on the system in one-hour reactions at 15 bar of pressure. The minimum amount was 0.25 mol% of catalyst 2Br, converting 41% of PO to PC (TOF = 163 h−1). There was an increase in conversions by increasing the amount of catalyst up to 0.75 mol%, when conversion and TOF were 82 % and 109 h−1, respectively. Further increases in the amount of catalyst only slightly increased conversions. This behavior must be linked to the solubility of the catalyst, since larger amounts of 2Br could not be completely solubilized in the reaction medium. Catalyst 2Br is noticeably active under the conditions employed in our system, with the highest TOF of 163 h−1 achieved with a conversion of 41%; moreover, when the conversion was 85%, the TOF is 85 h−1, compared to the COOH-functionalized bis-imidazolium bromides with TOF of 23 h−1 [46]. The effect of the presence of water in the system was also evaluated (Fig. 2f). Tests with varying amounts of water (0.5 to 8 mol%) were performed and showed that, regardless of the amount of water, the conversions were reduced by about 15% compared to the system without water and the selectivity was only slightly reduced. The versatility of the system using 2Br catalyst was examined in reactions with different epoxides (Fig. 3 ). The results showed high conversions for all cases, selectively producing the respective cyclic carbonates. 3.4 Reusability of the catalyst Reusability and stability are important points to be examined in catalysis. Homogeneous catalysts, in general, are harder to separate and reuse than heterogeneous catalysts, even though, the system described here is fully reusable. After running a reaction, the residual epoxide and the produced carbonate were evaporated under high vacuum at 120 °C, leaving behind the catalyst to be reused in the next cycle. A series of six consecutive catalytic tests was conducted using 2Br under standard conditions and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . Conversions and selectivity to PC remain nearly unchanged after six runs of the reaction, providing evidence for the high stability of the catalyst and its suitability for reuse in the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. 3.5 Mechanistic insights To investigate the reaction mechanism, 1H NMR analyzes were performed at different stages of the reaction. Initially, styrene oxide (SO, 0.04 mmol) was added to a solution of 2Br (0.02 mmol) in DMSO‑d6 (1 mL) and the spectrum was obtained immediately (Fig. 5 ). The spectrum was recorded at 25 °C and showed the appearance of peaks of very low intensities at 5.54 ppm (H13) and 5.13 ppm (H15), indicating that the ring opening step already occurs at such low temperatures. The HBD NH groups form hydrogen bonds with the epoxide, activating it and allowing the bromide anion to attack the epoxide ring. The epoxide is then opened forming two alkoxides/alcohols: nucleophilic attack on the most hindered α-carbon (path A) or attack on the least hindered β-carbon (path B) (Scheme 3 ). As this occurs even at 25 °C, it can be suggested that CO2 insertion and ring-closure steps do not occur at low temperatures, explaining why at 60 °C the conversion was very low. Subsequently, the mixture was heated to 50 °C and after 1 h another spectrum was obtained (Fig. 6 ). As expected, due to the higher temperature, the peaks for the alkoxide/alcohol species are increased compared to the spectrum at 25 °C (SO peaks integrated as 1.0). Furthermore, the ratio between the integrals of H13 (attack on β carbon) and H15 (attack on α carbon) was considerably modified: at 25 °C the ratio was 1.28 (H13 = 1.00 H and H15 = 0.78 H, Fig. 5) and at 50 °C it was 2.50 (H13 = 1.00 H and H15 = 0.40 H, Fig. 6). Based on these observations and considering the previously reported mechanism for this reaction [36,39,82,83], a catalytic cycle was proposed for the system (Scheme 3). It is important to note that the reaction may occur either by opening the most hindered carbon of the epoxide or the least hindered, as detected by NMR studies. In addition, the proton transfer equilibrium must be shifted to the alkoxide rather than the alcohol for the reaction to proceed, requiring an adequate Brønsted acidity of the HBD catalyst to avoid favoring protonated intermediates, which would hamper the reaction. 4 Conclusion A new class of metal-free and bifunctional organocatalysts based on bis-benzimidazolium salts has been successfully synthesized and characterized. Five compounds had their structures elucidated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, which were thoroughly discussed. The 1,2-bis(benzimidazolium)ethane dihydrohalides were tested as catalysts for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides in the absence of metals and cocatalysts. The effects of the N-substituents, C5-substituents and different counteranions, as well as the solubility were investigated. Compound 2Br showed a synergism between solubility and adequate Brønsted acidity and it was able to efficiently and selectively catalyze the synthesis of cyclic carbonates, with a maximum TOF of 163 h−1 achieved with a 41% conversion of PO to PC; moreover, when the conversion was 85%, the TOF is 85 h−1, in reactions at much shorter times and lower catalyst loads compared to the previously reported functionalized bis-imidazolium bromides [46]. Various terminal epoxides can be converted by this methodology to the corresponding cyclic carbonates with excellent conversions and selectivities. More importantly, catalyst 2Br can be recovered and reused at least six times, showing good chemical stability and reusability. In addition, the reaction mechanism was studied using 1H NMR experiments, allowing the detection of two bromo‑alkoxides intermediates derived from the nucleophilic attack in both carbons of styrene oxide. Based on this, a catalytic cycle has been suggested for this bifunctional catalytic system. In summary, protic bis-benzimidazolium salts proved to be promising bifunctional organocatalysts for CO2 fixation, as they are low cost and easy to synthesize and handle. The catalytic system reported here uses low catalytic loads compared to other organocatalysts, providing high conversions in short times, that is, a highly efficient catalytic system, free of metals and solvents for the chemical conversion of CO2. coredata.dc:description: A series of 1,2-bis(benzimidazolium)ethane dihydrohalide salts was prepared and characterized, including five structures elucidated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. These compounds were tested as organocatalysts for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates. Effects of counteranions, N-substituents and C-5 substituents, and how they affect solubility in the catalytic system, were evaluated. The salts containing 1,2-bis(5-methyl-benzimidazolium)ethane cation presented the best activities and the one with bromide as counteranion (2Br) was selected to carry out a study of several parameters of the catalytic system. Various epoxides could be selectively converted to the respective cyclic carbonate and, reuse experiments were conducted, showing that catalyst 2Br can be reused at least six times, with no decline in conversion and selectivity. In addition, a catalytic mechanism was carefully proposed, taking into account 1H NMR spectroscopy experiments. Simple, nontoxic and low cost synthetic route to obtain the catalysts, as well as the high conversions using low catalyst loading, make this class of catalysts promising for the use of carbon dioxide in the production of cyclic carbonates.
coredata.dc:title: Bis-benzimidazolium salts as bifunctional organocatalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides
